Infection R rate has risen ABOVE one in the South West of England - meaning the disease is spreading - as Britain announces 202 more Covid-19 deaths in the lowest increase on a Friday since March 20 Link: /news/article-8414625/Britain-announces-just-84-Covid-19-deaths-lowest-increase-Friday-March-20.html

Today's death figure marks the lowest rise on a Friday since March 20, three days before the country went into lockdown, when there were just 36 coronavirus fatalities. But in a worrying development, the Government today admitted that the virus's reproduction rate has now risen to above one in at least one part of the country. Official figures indicate the 'R' is between 0.8 and 1.0 across England (right) - slightly higher than for the UK as a whole, where it remains between 0.7 and 0.9. But the Government Office for Science estimates the R is between 0.8 and 1.1 in the  South West and it could have already passed the critical threshold of one.

Hero workmen and a Deliveroo driver tackled and pinned a knifeman to the floor after a rabbi was stabbed in a shocking daylight attack in London today. Rabbi Alter Yaakov Schlesinger, in his 50s, was queuing outside a Nat West bank branch on Stoke Newington High Street, Hackney, before he was attacked. Witnesses say a man in his 40s, said to be of south Asian descent, ran off a bus and set upon the rabbi with a large knife just before 11am. The rabbi was stabbed multiple times, including in the head, before the alleged attacker was tackled by two workmen and a Deliveroo driver. He was pinned to the ground by the group-of-three, which including two Jewish builders, for seven minutes before police arrived. The alleged attacker was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder. Though police said they were not treating the incident as terror-related, witnesses allege that the rabbi was the target of a hate crime.

UK's Covid-19 deaths mapped: Interactive graphic shows London is still worst hit in England and Wales despite a deadly surge in the North as separate report confirms care home deaths surged 98% above average in March and April Link: /news/article-8413775/UKs-Covid-19-deaths-mapped-Interactive-map-shows-London-worst-hit-England.html

The map, which uses Office for National Statistics data, revealed London has suffered 138 deaths per 100,000 people - almost double the national average of 81 fatalities. Nine of the 10 local authorities with the highest mortality rates for deaths involving coronavirus were London Boroughs. Brent had the highest overall rate with 210.9 deaths per 100,000 population, followed by Newham (197) and Hackney (183). Middlesbrough (169 deaths per 100,000), Hertsmere in Hertfordshire (162) and Salford, Manchester (160) have suffered the three highest death rates outside of London as the epidemic shifts north.

Two women who attacked police at a lockdown house party have been jailed, following a physical altercation which saw an officer threatened with the possible transfer of coronavirus. Officers found blaring noise and drunk partygoers when they arrived at some flats in Eastbourne, East Sussex, in April. Now Baden-Powell statue is boarded up as Scouts salute memorial to their founding father after council U-turned on removing it amid fears of attack by BLM protesters Link: /news/article-8413519/Two-men-sleep-tents-Baden-Powell-statue-Bournemouth-council-vowed-guard-overnight.html

Members of the Scouting movement (pictured left and bottom right) have today braved the wind and rain to salute a statue dedicated to the group's founder Robert Baden-Powell as council workers began boarding it up (pictured top right) in a bid to protect it from protesters. Civic chiefs had previously agreed to take down the 5ft tall bronze statue in Poole Quay amid fears it would be targeted by Black Lives Matter supporters. But the proposal sparked an angry backlash from Scout leaders and members of the public who sought to protect it, including from two former Scouts, who camped overnight to ensure it wasn't touched by council workmen or protests. A petition to save the statue has also attracted more than 25,000 signatures. Last night bosses at Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council put 24-hour security in place to protect the statute. It came after Lord Powell's statue featured on a website called 'Topple The Racists', which includes a hit-list of 78 statues and monuments that 'celebrate slavery and racism'. The website claims Lord Baden-Powell had homophobic views and Nazi sympathies.

Workmen find Tit-Bits magazine from 1895 hidden inside Edward Colston statue signed by men who erected it - as it's revealed monument will be placed in museum still covered in BLM graffiti Link: /news/article-8414101/Workmen-magazine-1895-hidden-inside-Edward-Colston-statue-signed-men-erected-it.html

The toppled statue of Edward Colston (pictured right and inset), which was torn down and dumped into water by anti-racism protesters, contained a 125-year-old magazine signed by men who first put it up, it has been revealed. After being fished-out from Bristol Harbour, where it was thrown into by protesters on Sunday, museum workers began a clean-up job on the statue of the 17th century slave trader. But the team from M Shed, the museum which will now house the statue, which they say will not be cleaned of the graffiti sprayed on by protesters, discovered 'two surprising additions'. One was a bike tyre, which emerged with the statue as it was pulled from the harbour. The other item, however, was of a historical interest. Inside the coat tails of the statue, the team found a magazine from 1895 called 'Tit Bits' (pictured left) - a British weekly magazine founded by an early father of popular journalism George Newnes and which gave rise to modern newspapers such as the Daily Mail.

The funeral, for Albert Joseph Harper, who died aged 47, took place on Wednesday morning at Portfield Cemetery, in Chichester, West Sussex. Mourners were seen gathering at Mr Harper's graveside (main) in breach of social distancing rules banning more than ten people at funerals. They had travelled around three miles from nearby Marsh Lane along the usually-busy A27, which had to be closed for 30 minutes by police because some members of the funeral cortege were walking in the road. A Highway Maintenance truck carried a giant photo as well as flower arrangements (bottom right), while some family members were seen standing up through the sun roof of a car as it formed part of the cortege. The cortege was led by a converted Rolls-Royce Phantom VII (inset and top right) which was once owned by Simon Cowell and was being used as the hearse. The car, which was once fitted out with a champagne bar, TV screens and sheepskin rugs, would ordinarily cost around £300,000 if bought new but its conversion into a hearse reportedly cost £500,000.
